prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
WIBTA if I make my gf start paying some of the bills over a single incident?
Gf and I live together.   She only works part time.    I pay all the rent and bill.  I never minded it until last night. 

We went to grab some take out and I realized I left my wallet in my work pants.  I told her she’d have to get it.   Her attitude about the whole thing was so ugly.   At first she couldn’t believe it and asked me if I was serious in this almost disgusted tone.  She acted so put out by it. 

It was some fucking take out.  Under $40.  I pay EVERYTHING.  I understand she only makes a little, but that little is probably a lot with no expenses.   I know it was only one incident, but I haven’t been able to get it out of my head since.   It’s really rubbing my the wrong way.  She wouldn’t be able to pay a lot of the bills, but I feel like it’s time for her to start carrying her weight.  Just out of principal.  
"""

I think the author is in the wrong but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's break this down. The user is asking if the person who wrote the "What Would You Do" scenario is in the wrong. The situation is about splitting bills in a relationship.

First, the author is in a relationship where he and his girlfriend live together. He pays all the bills because she works part-time, and he never had a problem with that until an incident where he asked her to pay for takeout. She reacted negatively, and now he wants her to start contributing more.

Hmm. So the key points here are: He's been covering all expenses, she works part-time, and the issue started after a single instance where she was upset about paying for a $40 takeout. He feels that because she makes some money, even if not a lot, she should start contributing, even if it's just in principle.

Now, the user thinks the author is in the wrong. Let me consider both sides. 

From the author's perspective: He's been shouldering all the financial responsibility. The argument is that even a small contribution would be fair, especially since she has some income. The incident with the takeout made him realize he wants her to take on more responsibility. Maybe he feels taken for granted or that she's not contributing as a partner. The $40 was a small amount, but it's about principle. 

From the girlfriend's perspective: She works part-time, which might mean she has a limited income. Maybe she's already managing her expenses, and being asked to pay for the takeout, even a small amount, feels like an added burden. Her reaction might stem from feeling that the author has never asked her to contribute before, so this sudden request is unexpected and perhaps resented. The way he told her she "had to get it" might have come off as abrupt or dismissive of her financial situation.

Is the author in the wrong? Well, he's been handling all the bills up to this point, which could be seen as part of their arrangement. The girlfriend wasn't expecting to contribute because that's how it's always been. The author is now changing the dynamic based on a single incident. That might be unfair to her, especially if she wasn't consulted about splitting costs before. 

Also, the way he reacted—calling her attitude "ugly" and being disgusted—might have been harsh. Maybe the issue is more about communication. Instead of using a $40 incident as a catalyst to change the financial arrangement, a more open conversation about shared responsibilities would have been better. 

So, the author might be in the wrong because he's shifting the financial burden without considering their existing agreement and the sudden change could be seen as unfair. The girlfriend's reaction might be valid if she felt blindsided. The author's approach seems to be using a minor incident to justify a larger change, which isn't necessarily fair. Therefore, the answer might be A (the author is in the wrong).
